physDesc.p: This letter is 5 pages long. It is typed on carbon paper. The date is in the top right, and to the left of the date on each page is a backwards slash with 46 above it. There is an annotation at the top of the page starting on the second page (Mr. Aldington - [Page #]). There is a certificate of issue after page 2, before page 3.

div.p: Your letter of January 5th came a day or two ago and has given me great pleasure. I am delighted to know that the “Anglo-French Review” has “One, Two, Three” and “Summer Night Piece.” Of course a guinea is a ludicrous price; over here I get $25.00 for short poems and more according to length. Sometimes I get a great deal more, sometimes as much as $100.00, but here I am somebody while in England I am nobody, and I am glad to have a chance to publish there even at the price of a guinea.

I think your idea of publishing the things in “Coterie” most excellent, but I am sorry to have Aiken in it as Aiken is one of solidest enemies over here. The man has me on the brain. Evidently I annoy him. I notice in his book, “ScepticismsSkepticisms,” that I am mentioned more times than any one else in the book, and almost always in wrath. I am sort of a complex with him, and really, from the way he takes it, it is almost a compliment to be so perpetually in his thought even if he does not like me. However, if “Coterie” will take these things of mine, I quite agree with you that the publicity is valuable.

You say you have two poems of mine; I think you have three, if I am not mistaken: “Granadilla,” “Carrefour,” and “Paradox.” Kindly tell me which two you have, since I must keep track of these things as I am constantly having applications for poems.

“The Dial,” as you know, has changed hands, also its format and its whole point of view. I thought Martyn Johnson had paid up all his debts before going to the South Seas, whither he has retired to hide his chagrin. The new owner is a man named Schofield Thayer. I do not know him. I meant to see him in New York a couple of weeks ago, but I did not have time. However,
I shall try to see him when I am in New York in June, and mention your claim for $20.00.

It amuses me to know that the “London Times” only has a circulation of 34,000. How small the scale in England is compared to that of America! I do not know what the circulation is of the “New York Times,” for which I write, but I think a million and a half is nearer the figure.

What you say of the animosity of the Poetry Bookshop is one of the things that most annoys me. When Harold Monro wrote me of his resuming “Poetry and Drama” under a new form, I wrote him and suggested that he should allow me to have one of the issues to write a simple resumé of American poetry, with illustrations. He waited about five months before answering me, and then said that he thought the idea was a good one, but that he had already given it into other hands before my letter reached him. Now I am afraid he has given it into the hands of Charles Wharton Stork, who runs a very feeble paper over here. Stork's interests are entirely reactionary, he publishes the poorest poetry written to-day, and his little paper, to which people contribute gratuitously, has no standing whatever. He is always discovering poets whom nobody ever hears of. I really believe he is the worst poet in the world himself, and anything but a gentleman to boot. He came to call on me, the other day, and made a pleasant afternoon call, and went away and told everything I said to a Philadelphia paper as if it had been an interview.

The reason I think he has been entrusted with this issue is because he told me he had also written to Monro asking for it, but at the time he was here he had not received an answer. If Monro puts himself in the hands of Stork, he will have the most ludicrous misrepresentation of American poetry that could possibly be given. How they do go wrong, Richard, and how anxious they are apparently to choose the wrong people to inform them.
I wonder who is doing the American notes for the “Times.” From what you say, it is undoubtedly the same thing there.

What you say about my own books gives me great pleasure. I had an idea that you did not like my books very much, taking them by and large. They have recently been taken over by Basil Blackwell who is very much interested in them, and I hope the public will back him up a little as he is taking all the risks. He would not even take the sheets from Macmillan, as he thought he could print more cheaply over there. I have no doubt he is right, but of course it makes a tremendous risk for him. He is to bring out “Can Grande” this Spring, and follow with the other volumes at six month intervals if the sale of “Can Grande” warrants his so doing.

Who will review it for the “Times,” you or who? Reviews make or mar a book so much in England, and there is not a soul I know of who will speak favourably of it except possibly yourself. Winifred writes that she would like to review it if she were to be in England, but as she is going to Greece, I suppose that will go by the board. My work will probably go slowly at first as it did here, but I have no real doubt about my future in England.

At last we are waking up to the fact that we have American poets and that they are some good. You will be amused to learn that I have been offered the degree of Doctor of Literature by a Western University, which high honour I am to be invested in at Commencement next June. As I Believe I am the first of the modern poets, man or woman, to receive an academic recognition of this kind, I am a good deal amused.

I do not know whether you have a Phi Beta Kappa society in England. It consists of the first ten scholars in every graduating class, and is supposed to be, therefore, the greatest body of intelligent men which can
exist. Every year, each chapter of the Phi Beta Kappa has a meeting at which an orator and a poet are chosen to speak, at Commencement, and I have been asked to deliver the Phi Beta Kappa poem at Columbia University this June. I gave the Phi Beta Kappa poem at Tuft's College some years ago, but Columbia is a much larger university. So you see things are moving. These details, of course, do not matter a button really. They are usually given to the wrong people, and I am probably one of the wrong ones, but they do show a desire on the part of the public to help a native poet.

What you say about not being able to get interested in anything does not surprise me at all. The soldiers I have seen are all the same. Of course the shock of what you have been through is terrific, and it will take some time to get over it, but your interest will come back, my dear boy, it is certain to come back as you grow stronger.

I am delighted that you are on the “Times,” for that is a permanent something to cling to and keep you going until the urge for poetry writing comes back, and even then I do not think it is too arduous for you to do your own work on the side. I often review for the “Times” here, and although it takes a good deal of time, you know my theory that one should do these things as the professionals do them, even though one does not have to work, but can sit on a cushion and create as one likes.

I do not agree with your opinion of Masefield's “Reynard the Fox.” I think that it a fine thing of its kind, but perhaps I am more eclectic than you are. Is that because I have less critical faculty, or because I am older? Who knows.

By the way, Michael SadlerMichael Sadleir has asked me to send him some of my poems for a little paper called “Voices,” the editor of which seems to like
my work, and on the theory that it is better to be read even if unpaid, I did so. I wish I could come over to England, but I am to have an operation next week. It is a nuisance because it cuts off the rest of my Winter, and it will be some time before I am able to work again, but it cannot be helped. I have waited too long as it is.
